Experience Analog IC Design Engineer Intel Corporation May 2011  – Present (4 years 4 months) I work in a group that does "special circuits", which means that we do outside-the-box designs. Basically, I do analog design. Electrical Engineering Intern Intel Corporation September 2010  –  May 2011  (9 months) For this internship, I am working in Intel's ECG group as a systems engineer. We do platform validation, which is basically a motherboard that has FPGAs to control everything to test all of Intel's brand-new chips. Naturally, there are a LOT of interfaces on this board (SPI, SMBus, PCIe, SATA...to name a few) so it provided a great learning experience for me, as well as a fun one because I enjoy learning more and more about how PCs work. 
 
My main intern project is to write software to communicate with supplied drivers from FTDI to utilize three interfaces: I2C(SMBus), SPI, and JTAG. So, I had to write a program that would use each interface as needed. A fairly lengthy project. 
 
I also worked directly on debug of our platform. It was built to test a specific PCH that Intel was developing at the time. I also participated in a power-on, which was a fantastic, if not unbelievably tiring, experience. 
 
Finally, I led a team of PSU students designing a memory voltage regulator for standard DDR memory. This module was able to plug into the board to supply the ~75 Watts (max) necessary to power the memory. Teaching Assistant Purdue University August 2008  –  May 2010  (1 year 10 months) Currently I am teaching two lab sections, two "DPS" (Directed Problem Solving) sections, and holding three hours of office hours per week for the course ECE270. This is a basic course on digital system design. 
 
During the summer, I was promoted to "Course Instructor" for ECE202, "Linear Circuit Analysis II". This is Purdue's second circuit theory class which covers s-domain analysis, convolution, transformers, and two-port circuits. As Course Instructor, I was in charge of preparing and presenting lectures, writing and grading exams, and assisting students whenever necessary. 
 
In the Spring of 2010, I was honored as a recipient of both the Magoon award for TA excellence and the CETA teaching award. Both are only given to a select few students, and to have both honors speaks to my communication ability and understanding of the coursework. Electrical Engineering Intern Garmin International May 2008  –  August 2008  (4 months) This was my second internship at Garmin International. My project was to redesign the output circuitry for the fishfinders 300c and 400c, as well as variations of those models. Originally, the work was only to encompass finding a new turns ratio for the output step-up transformer, but I completed that quickly and moved on to designing a new output power supply, which was a switching supply able to handle more current, and was significantly cheaper than the previous version. This addition was significant because one of the main marketing specifications is the output power, which I was able to increase while saving money at the same time. In my spare time, I was also able to help the other more senior engineers with their projects where I learned more about the project cycle in a large company and compliance testing procedures. Part-Time Electrical Engineering Intern Advanced Manufacturing Institute September 2007  –  May 2008  (9 months) At AMI, I was originally hired to work on a rebar sensor being developed for KDOT. I finished and organized the previous work that had been done, and had a design ready to pass to the PCB designers. Since I again completed my first project ahead of schedule, I also worked on several other projects. First, I diagnosed two different problems in two different broken milling machines. One I was able to fix on-site and the other was fixed after ordering a new part. Yet another project I worked on was a project for KDOT that uses an RF link to estimate a car's wait time for the "pilot car" in a construction zone where traffic has been reduced to one-way. Electrical Engineering Intern Garmin International May 2007  –  August 2007  (4 months) This was my first internship with Garmin International. For this internship, my project was to work on a wireless link between sensors and the main hub for the marine team. The wireless protocol I used was called "wireless ANT" and is developed by Dynastream. I successfully got the link to work in our controlled workplace. I also performed a significant amount of range testing for the wireless mouse and remote. Electrical Engineering S and Y Industries May 2006  –  August 2006  (4 months) For the first half of this internship, I acquired valuable hands-on experience and intimate knowledge by building products and soldering different components. For the second half of the internship, I worked in the QC department where I tested the final products and troubleshot the broken circuits. In this arena, I developed my basic logical troubleshooting skills that are still with me today. Summary An Instructor at UC Berkeley Extension and a Smart Grid  
Enthusiast that created Smart Grid Technology curriculum and  
developed 7 courses for the curriculum. 
 
A catalyst for success that has developed and shipped  
3 SPARC Microprocessor Chips, 1 SPARC Server and 2  
Workstations at Sun with millions to billions of dollars of  
recognized revenue, and 1 Director Class SAN Switch  
at a start-up company. 
 
A problem-solver, activity facilitator, and a mentor for team members. 
 
Comprehensive hands-on engineering experience starts with  
concept and architecture, going through stages of engineering  
design, integration, and test, to delivering the final design to  
volume production. 
 
Extensive first-hand leadership experience in all phases  
of developing chip and system products including attracting  
& retaining top talent, team building, project planning,  
managing schedule and deliverable, integrating and  
orchestrating engineering teams of different expertise  
and disciplines, coordinating product life cycle compliance  
and releasing engineering design to production. Specialties:* Created and teaching Smart Grid curriculum at UC Berkeley Extension 
* Designed Multiprocessor System Platforms and Director Class SAN Switch 
* High-tech Team Leadership and Management 
* Registered Practitioner of PRINCE2 (P2R/267233) Project Management Methodology 
* Bilingual in English and Mandarin 
* Design for Six Sigma  
* Change Management 
* Coaching, Mentoring, and Facilitation

Instructor UC Berkeley Extension August 2009  – Present (6 years 1 month) * Created Smart Grid curriculum by developing a suite of  
7 courses including "Introduction to Smart Grid" (X423),  
“Energy Transmission and Distribution” (X423.1),  
“Command and Control Networks” (X423.2),  
“Metering and Home Area Networks” (X423.3),  
“Internet of Things” (X423.4), “Smart Microgrid” (X432.5),  
and "Energy Efficient Buildings" (X432.6).  
* Taught Smart Grid courses at UC Berkeley Extension and  
San Jose State University to various audiences including 
hi-tech professionals in silicon valley, top executives of Software 
and Information Technology Industry from Jiangsu Province of 
China, and professors in Software and Information Technology 
field from 16 universities across China. 
* Enriched Engineering Technology curriculum by developing  
“PRINCE2 Project Management Foundation” (X435.4) and “Digital  
Logic Design” (X421) courses for 2009 academic year. Senior Engineering Manager Sun Microsystems Inc. July 2003  –  March 2009  (5 years 9 months) UltraSPARC-IV+ Microprocessor Chip:  
 
* Contributed to Sun’s ~$6B - $7B a year Enterprise Server  
products by leading UltraSPARC-IV+ microprocessor chip design  
team’s Product Life Cycle compliance effort and liaising with  
server system bring-up team, new product introduction team,  
and operations team. 
 
OpenSPARC: 
 
* Orchestrated OpenSPARC 2008 Workshop in Beijing. Elaborated  
OpenSPARC architecture and articulated the value proposition  
in Mandarin to 20+ professors and their PhD students from  
18 top echelon universities across China. 
 
* Mentored 6 engineers and engineering managers at Sun to help  
them with their careers and win promotions under SEED (Sun  
Engineering Enrichment and Development) mentoring program 
and Mentoring@Sun program. Director of Hardware Systems Group Sanera Systems Inc. (Acquired by McData Corporation February 2001  –  July 2003  (2 years 6 months) * Led successful development of DS10000 director class Fibre  
Channel SAN switch by building a team of 24 system design  
engineers and directing the project of architecture/performance  
modeling and system hardware implementation. 
* Enabled DS10000 to become McData Corporation’s ~$80M a year  
Intrepid i10K Director product by delivering Sanera’s DS10000  
prototype for demonstration at 2003 Storage Network World  
conference. Senior Engineering Manager Sun Microsystems Inc. September 1996  –  February 2001  (4 years 6 months) * Enabled successful development of UltraSPARC-III  
microprocessor chip, awarded as 2001 Analyst Choice of Best  
Workstation/Server Microprocessor by Microprocessor Report,  
by building a team of 26 RTL design engineers from original  
size of 4 and managing the design and verification of  
Multiprocessor (MP) system interconnect interface and the  
external memory unit (EMU) as one of the most critical  
feature of Sun’s Advanced Multiprocessor System Architecture  
of Enterprise Server product line. 
* Collaborated in delivering Sun's $7B - $8B a year  
UltraSPARC-III/III+ chips based Workstations and  
Enterprise Servers product lines by building a microprocessor  
chip Stand-Alone-Test (SAT) model and releasing to  
6 system design teams to enable successful completion  
of their system verification task.  
* Enabled successful volume production of UltraSPARC-III/III+  
microprocessor chips by championing the Product Life Cycle  
compliance effort and managing post-silicon debug and system  
bring-up support. 
* Established the initial feature set of UltraSPARC-IV+ microprocessor  
chip as a mid-generation performance booster by building a  
6-engineer team and managing architecture and performance  
modeling. Staff Engineer and Senior Staff Engineer Sun Microsystems Inc. February 1987  –  September 1996  (9 years 8 months) SPARCserver-490 and SPARCserver-470: 
 
* Helped delivering Sun's ~$800M a year SPARCserver-490  
and SPARCserver-470 product line by architecting and  
designing the virtually tagged and virtually indexed IO cache  
for the server systems. 
 
SuperSPARC based SPARCstation-10-SX: 
 
* Contributed to delivering Sun's ~$200M a year SPARCstation-10SX  
workstation product line by developing and designing  
the load/store unit of an integer vector processor  
based memory controller ASIC chip as a graphics and image  
processing acceleration engine for SPARCstation-10SX workstation. Received Engineering Excellence Award. 
 
HyperSPARC based SPARCstation-20/10/10-SX: 
 
* Collaborated in delivering Sun's ~400M a year  
HyperSPARC based SPARCstation-10/10SX/20  
workstations product line by managing post-silicon debug  
and system validation. Provided engineering support for  
Pixar's cartoon movie "Toy Story". 
 
UltraSPARC-III based Workstations and Enterprise Servers: 
 
* Facilitated decision making and trade-offs between hardware  
and software features for Sun’s UltraSPARC-III microprocessor  
chip based Workstations and Enterprise Servers by chairing  
hardware-software forum. Systems IC Design Engineer Ford Microelectronics Inc.
